name: Salaama Restaurant
author: Susan Kelleher
description: The Somali eatery caters to East African clients and English-speaking travelers with equal hospitality. Breakfast offerings consist of sauteed meats — chicken, liver or beef — or pinto beans, served with a choice of injera (a spongy sourdough pancake), pita bread or mufo, a Somali cornbread. Lunch/dinner choices include suqaar, chicken or beef sauteed with onion, parsley, tomatoes, cumin and garlic; roasted goat; and chicken, beef or fish shawarma.

name: Marlaina's Mediterranean Kitchen
author: Susan Kelleher
description: This spot wears its heart on its sleeve, with owner intent on making this a warm, family restaurant. Entrees feature kebabs with salmon, chicken, beef, lamb or combo, kofte, minced lamb and beef, chicken nutmeg and slow-braised beef or chicken stew. All come with a scoop of basmati rice and a small green salad. And don't miss the baba ganoosh.

name: Evviva Woodfired Pizza
author: Katrina Barlow
description: Patrons have called Evviva Woodfired Pizza the best pizza in Seattle, which is quite the feat for a restaurant in Edmonds. But, one slice in, it's no surprise that Evviva's reputation for Neapolitan-style pizza has far outgrown its small berth up north. Customer favorites are often the seasonal pies, like the spring smoked-salmon pizza or the fall chanterelle pizza.

name: Red Star Taco Bar
author: Katrina Barlow
description: The Lenin statue stares in Red Star’s direction, probably thinking about the tortilla-chip-crusted catfish tacos. The pomegranate slushy margarita hits sweet-tart exactly right. The place is relaxed, and the owners, two former neighborhood bartenders, don’t tolerate Fremont overindulgers on (wooooo!) weekend nights.

name: Hokkaido Ramen Santouka
author: Providence Cicero
description: This might be the best ramen in Western Washington. Everything from miso to the soy-sauce based is excellent — rich, with bold flavors that surprisingly don’t drown out the lighter ingredients. The ramen is topped with buttery pieces of braised pork belly.

name: Dough Zone
author: Mark Yuasa
description: Its extensive menu is a carb lover's delight with 18 varieties of dumplings that come steamed, boiled or pan-fried. The juicy pork soup dumplings rival the ones served at nearby "big box" dumpling restaurant Din Tai Fung.

name: Big Chickie
author: Tan Vinh
description: This shack in Hillman City quickly gained a following for its Peruvian-style rotisserie chicken, especially for the charred skin and citrusy, dark meat. Twenty-two bucks get you a whole chicken with two sides, four cornbread muffins and three dipping sauces. It’s several notches better than your typical supermarket rotisserie takeout.

name: Midori Bakery
author: Tan Vinh
description: Midori started as a modest coffee-and-pastry counter in a warehouse in the back of an industrial area in Redmond. Thanks to a cult following for its croissants, Midori moved into bigger digs in 2014, expanding into a bakery and cafe, serving sandwiches from baguettes baked every morning to dense Kouign-amanns to sink your teeth into.

name: Saimin Says
author: Mark Yuasa
description: This unassuming West Valley strip-mall joint has been serving up island favorites since 2010. In addition to 12 varieties of saimin — a Hawaiian-style noodle similar to ramen — there are 16 different plate lunches ranging from kalua pig and cabbage; tonkatsu, breaded deep-fried pork; mahi-mahi, a mild Hawaiian white fish; or a combo of marinated teriyaki-style chicken and thinly sliced beef.

name: Slab Sandwiches + Pie
author: Tan Vinh
description: John Sundstrom’s Capitol Hill lunch counter serves gloriously fatty, glistening cuts of meat. To die for: the smoked brisket sandwich, amped up with smoked mayo and seared romaine lettuce, plus pickled jalapeños to cut into the salty, smoky richness.

name: Cafetal Quilombo Cafe
author: Susan Kelleher
description: The secret is out: Some of the area’s best tamales are sold out of this coffee shop along a stretch of apartments and bungalows on Beacon Hill. The owners, from Aguascalientes, Mexico, hawk eight different kinds from behind the espresso bar. The must-have (when it’s not sold out) is the spicy pork with red sauce.

name: Neon Taco
author: Tan Vinh
description: Located in the back of the dive bar Nacho Borracho, this kitchen from talented young chef Monica Dimas features contemporary takes on tacos and other Mexican street food for the bar hoppers and potheads who frequent (or stumble along) Broadway at night.

name: Blue Stone Bistro
author: Katrina Barlow
description: Fancy new places are focusing on Korean food (which recently attained “trend” status), but this family-run spot on the curve of Olive Way makes it very tasty, without any fuss. Get a fried egg on top of your hot-stone-bowl bibimbap — it’s free.

name: Triple XXX Root Beer Drive-in
author: Mark Yuasa
description: Just off I-90 on the east side of downtown Issaquah is a giant orange wooden-barrel sign, marking the location of this 'Happy Days'-era eatery. Just about every inch of the walls and ceilings is covered with car and other classic memorabilia. It's burgers (18 varieties) and fries all the way, but don't skip a float or a shake to go with.

name: Kraken Congee
author: Tan Vinh
description: It didn’t hurt that world-renowned chef José Andrés ate here and tweeted about it. This subterranean space in Pioneer Square elevates rice porridge by dressing it up with cured egg yolk, five-spice duck confit and pork belly adobo, but don’t miss its Filipino twist on pork-belly buns.

name: Kozue
author: Misha Berson
description: This cozy haunt keeps the price reasonable for both its raw and cooked fare, while maintaining the freshness, taste and variety that make you come back for more. The sushi and sashimi plates are satisfyingly fresh and filling, and you can design a meal from the many appetizers.

name: MonGa Cafe
author: Mark Yuasa
description: The expansive menu features Taiwanese-style specialties that satisfy the meat-lover or vegetarian. The cafe also strives to be healthy by using less salt and oil. Must-haves include the beef noodle soup and Lu-Rou, a slow-cooked pork delight.

name: Planet Java
author: Tyrone Beason
description: This homey Pioneer Square greasy spoon is a shout-out to the simple, cheap and hearty fare of the of yesteryear. Open for breakfast and lunch only, they do the classics — eggs and omlettes, sandwiches and fries — at very reasonable prices.

name: Urban Sushi Kitchen
author: Katrina Barlow
description: Tucked in a boxy downtown office building, this spot is a handy hideaway for well-priced, quality sushi. Order from the menu of more than 50 rolls, or check out the kitchen items like udon or pepper-seared tuna.

name: BRGR Bar
author: Tan Vinh
description: Some tricked-out, gluttonous burgers are featured including one topped with smoked pork belly, fried egg and exotic condiments. The kitchen also does an expanded dinner menu of food-truck-inspired bites and Korean comfort food. Note the full menu isn't offered when there's a Mariners, Seahawks or Sounders home game. Lunch and dinner, hours vary; closed Sunday.

name: Tung Kee Mi Gia
author: Susan Kelleher
description: Situated in an aesthetically challenged stretch of Burien, this hole-in-the-wall nevertheless delivers tasty food in generous portions, at prices that will please. The huge menu is dominated by noodle soups and fried-rice offerings in head-spinning combinations. If you're ordering to go, be sure to pick up some condiments to spice things up at home.

name: Country Dough
author: Brian Thomas Gallagher
description: Tucked away in Pike Place Market, this cubby-sized spot specializes in guo kui, a stuffed flatbread popular in China as street food. The pastry pillows have a pleasing crackle of an exterior, with soft, warm Szechuan spiced goodness stuffed inside. But don't skip the silky crepes or hand-shaved noodles.

name: Paseo
author: Bethany Jean Clement
description: Paseo reopened in early 2015 under new ownership, and thus Seattle’s most famous sandwich rides again. The recipe wasn’t part of the deal, but the revived version, created with original employees’ help, is just as messy — and some say just as good.

name: Un Bien
author: Bethany Jean Clement
description: From the sons of the original owner of Paseo, this nearby sandwich shop has a familiar tropical-pink paint job and a likewise Caribbean roast-pork sandwich. Is the marinade’s flavor more nuanced? Is the sandwich better? Only your mouth can tell you.

name: Wayback Burgers
author: Mark Yuasa
description: Modeled after a 1950s-style roadside burger joint, the Bellevue branch of this franchise offers handmade burgers featuring fresh ingredients. Don't skip the chili-cheese fries and thick milkshakes.

name: Manao Thai Street Eats
author: Tyrone Beason
description: Standing out in a town with more than 100 Thai restaurants is no easy task. But Manao Thai Street Eats manages to do just that with the buzzing atmosphere and vivid flavors one would expect on the busy streets of Thailand.

name: Little Oddfellows
author: Brian Gallagher
description: A little sister to her Oddfellows Cafe two doors down, Linda Derschang's prettied-up coffee counter inside Elliott Bay Book Co. is a welcoming place to thumb through potential purchases. A rotating daily selection of baguette sandwiches, quiche and baked goods welcome hungry booksters.

name: Vaca Loca the Latin Taste
author: Susan Kelleher
description: The Cuban sandwich at this Capitol Hill cubby is worth the trip on its own. But the rest of the dishes crisscross borders to bring a selection of Latin dishes to satisfy any craving you might have, from mole enchiladas to Colombian beef stew. Don't miss the chilaquiles on the brunch menu.

name: The Faerie Queene
author: Bethany Jean Clement
description: This little place has an odd name (from an unfinished Elizabethan epic poem), keeps strange hours (read on) and is easy to overlook among Pioneer Square's more acclaimed options, but it's a surprisingly sweet deal. Chef/owner Una Kim prepares seafood, sandwiches and more with care, and she has a magic way with spiciness.

name: Arashi Ramen
author: Mark Yuasa
description: The hearty, deeply flavored pork-bone broth is simmered for 16 hours at this South End spot. Choose from nine different styles of ramen or try any of the tasty appetizers, like chicken karaage.

name: Obbar Pocha
author: Tyrone Beason
description: The fusion Korean-American menu at this Chinatown International District spot is a witty yet respectful take on the sort of food-cart fare one might find in Seoul. Don't miss the selection of beef, pork and tuna burgers sandwiched between ingenious "buns" made of either sticky rice or noodles that somehow hold together when you bite into them.

name: Pellegrini Italian Market
author: Susan Kelleher
description: The sandwiches at this West Seattle spot are unapologetically old-school Italian, a celebration of bread and cheese, cured meats and roasted veggies that verges on overkill. They're available as subs, grilled panini or 7-inch folded pizzas. Don't forget the napkins.

name: Macleod's Fish & Chips
author: Tan Vinh
description: This Ballard joint seems to take its cue from Euro pubs and the state fair. The menu features deep-fried Snickers, deep-fried pizza along with Scotch egg and shepherd's pie. The signature fish-and-chips is what folks order, though, a thick cod fillet with a crispy shell.

name: Villa Escondida
author: Brian Thomas Gallagher
description: Everything at this Belltown standout is house-made, and you can taste it. Even the basics are terrific: handmade tortillas, fresh-fried chips and salsas you'll want to take home by the quart. Oaxacan cuisine is a specialty, so the mole is a must. But there's seemingly nothing bad on the menu, so order freely.

name: Dong Thap Noodles
author: Bethany Jean Clement
description: Does Dong Thap have Seattle's best noodles? The owner's family has been in the rice-noodle business in Vietnam for four generations, and here, rice is ground on site to make them every day. The pho noodles taste uncommonly fresh and massively better than most; the vermicelli in the bun is delicate, almost rich, sticky but still light. Dining deals don't come much better than Dong Thap.

name: CaliBurger
author: Bethany Jean Clement
description: This In-N-Out imitator in the U District might just be as good as the cult-favorite chain, and if not, it’s pretty damn close. One major plus: scooped-to-order boozy milkshakes. Another: the fact that it actually exists in Seattle, while In-N-Out has only made it as far north as Oregon.

name: Heyday
author: Mark Yuasa
description: Nine burgers headline the menu at this bustling Mount Baker spot — including a verde, smoky lamb, bison, jerk chicken, bacon bleu and codwich. Each is cooked to order and comes on a Macrina Bakery potato bun that holds the high-rise one-third-pound grass-fed beef burger well. An Udi's gluten-free bun is available upon request. And don't miss the double-fried French fries.

name: Queen Bee Cafe
author: Tyrone Beason
description: For the uninitiated, crumpets, apparently of English origin, are warm, spongy griddle cakes. This Queen Anne spot (with a sister restaurant on Madison Street) takes crumpets to a new level, though, with offerings that venture well beyond the traditional. The larger 'crumpwiches' include versions with honey-baked ham, fried egg and cheese, jerk chicken and prime roast beef.

name: Noble Barton
author: Susan Kelleher
description: At this White Center newcomer, the eclectic menu is heavy on the meat front but sprinkled with one-off items such as the seared ahi sandwich with wasabi-sesame guacamole and duck-confit flautas. A casual bar-restaurant that feels a little like a lodge with gorgeous wood floors and rich earth tones on the walls, this family friendly pub also has a kids menu.

name: Tortas Condesa
author: Tan Vinh
description: This walk-up window from Monica Dimas of nearby Neon Taco devotes itself entirely to a Mexican street food favorite: the torta. These meaty, salty and creamy sandwiches are more like beer-sponges, tailored for the late-night bar-hoppers on the Hill.

name: General Porpoise
author: Brian Gallagher
description: This Capitol Hill coffee-and-doughnut spot from star chef Renee Erickson serves only variations of filled doughnuts, but they are delicious. Perfectly raised and fried dough is complemented by fillings like lemon curd, vanilla custard and cherry jelly. Get there early: They have a habit of selling out.

name: El Sirenito
author: Bethany Jean Clement
description: This next-door sibling of beloved Georgetown spot Fonda La Catrina focuses on wild-caught fish and local produce, with excellent results — including what are arguably Seattle's best fish tacos. Add an entirely pleasant setting, very good cocktails and remarkably low prices, and it's more than well worth going out of your way. (It's technically a bar, so no kids allowed.)

name: Ramen Yoshi
author: Mark Yuasa
description: At this Bellevue spot, choose from seven different styles of piping hot ramen. The 'topping all' option — with slices of pork chashu, a soft-boiled egg, bamboo shoots and nori — is a particularly good bet. But regardless the variety, the thick egg noodles are done to just the right texture. Lunch and dinner; closed Sunday.

name: The Cajun Crawfish
author: Tyrone Beason
description: The emphasis is on seafood with a Vietnamese-Cajun twist, meaning clear-plastic bags of crawfish, shrimp, crabs, prawns, mussels and sea snails, all ordered by the pound at current market prices and smothered in a choice of buttery, lemony, peppery, garlicky sauces. Plastic bib and gloves included.
address: 6951 Martin Luther King Jr. Way S., Suite 103, Seattle

name: Bread and Circuses at The Woods
author: Susan Kelleher
description: The crew at this Sodo spot have created something akin to the garage band of kitchens, a place to jam out and experiment for fun and pleasure. The menu rotates depending on what's in season, and the chef's mood, but expect dishes like duck fat popcorn dusted with yeast; gnocchi tots; and a Brussels sprouts Caesar salad.

name: Amandine Bakeshop
author: Brian Gallagher
description: Alongside the Empire Espresso caffeinated concoction of your choice, expect a full slate of baked French delights from pastry virtuoso Sara Naftaly. Macarons are the specialty, but almond croissants, brioche and sacristans are all delicious and delicate.

name: Huong Duong
author: Tan Vinh
description: A favorite lunch spot of the refugee community in the Rainier Valley, Huong Duong is known for its cheap comfort food, served in copious amounts. Its best values are the two pork chops caramelized over the grill with fish sauce and served with a fried egg and rice; or the 'Grilled Noodle Bowl' with spring rolls, shrimp and pork over a bed of vermicelli.
address: 7136 Martin Luther King Jr. Way S., Seattle

name: Resonate Brewery and Pizzeria
author: Mark Yuasa
description: The 'Alla-Romana-Style Pizza' dough at this South Bellevue spot is fermented for three to five days. It takes on a golden-brown crust that is airy and soft, yet slightly chewy within. A stone oven straight from Italy does its work in about seven minutes, crisping the pizza both underneath and on top.

name: La Teranga
author: Tyrone Beason
description: This sliver of a restaurant turns out excellent West African fare inspired by the owner's native Senegal. The intricate, spicy flavors of West Africa come through in entrees like thiebou djeun, fish cooked in a tangy, peppery tomato stew with carrots, cassava, eggplant and cabbage; and lamb mafe, cooked with carrots, yams and cassava in peanut sauce.

name: Itto's Tapas
author: Susan Kelleher
description: This spot serves up an artful selection of Moroccan fusion dishes at prices that encourage your return. The offerings were sufficiently varied in texture, flavor and heat to keep things consistently interesting, and the friendly, attentive service kept the goodness coming at a perfect pace. Add stiff craft cocktails and an eclectic crowd, and you've got the makings of a wonderful evening.

name: La Cabana
author: Tan Vinh
description: Comfort food from Nicaragua, Guatemala, Costa Rica, El Salvador and Honduras is the focus. Get the sample platter with three appetizers (two deep-fried vegetarian crescent pies and a pupusa), three small portions of carne asada, chicharron and chorizo and served with avocado slices and a fried egg over rice and beans.

name: Taqueria Los Potrillos
author: Bethany Jean Clement
description: House-made tortillas are the base for bargain-priced, generally good takes on taqueria favorites at this White Center spot. Don't miss the fish tacos, featuring super-crispy, ungreasy pieces of white fish, and be sure to stop by the condiment bar.

name: Hurry Curry of Tokyo
author: Mark Yuasa
description: At this South Lake Union location for a Los Angeles-based place, curry rules, and they're not afraid to take some risks. Try the chicken katsu curry. The Yoshoku dishes, which put a Western spin on Japanese-style cuisine, may seem a bit off the wall, but they are worth a try.

name: Union Bar
author: Tyrone Beason
description: This union-themed pub is a good, laid-back spot for anyone in the mood for bar food" laborers and office dwellers alike. Both the sweet and savory stuffed squash and the hefty Union Burger are good bets on the menu.

name: Kedai Makan
author: Providence Cicero
description: The popular Malaysian hawker-style stall expanded into a full-service-restaurant and bar right around the corner on Capitol Hill, but it didn’t forget its success grew from the penny-pinchers who were its faithful patrons. And yes, the beloved roti and fried rice are on the new menu.

name: Burien Fish House
author: Susan Kelleher
description: From the owners of popular Seattle food truck Fish Basket, this Burien restaurant is a hit. Housed in an eclectic mini-mall, the focus here is fish, from classic fried seafood and chips to lobster and crab rolls. Don't miss the fried cod tacos, thin and crispy, and swimming in a tangy pico de gallo.

name: Vietnam House
author: Tan Vinh
description: It's one of the most popular restaurants in the Vietnamese community, with comfort fare that conjure images of food stalls and honking horns from mopeds on the streets of Saigon. Its specialty: the"Broken Rice' dish, listed as No. 49 on the menu, a mound of rice (nutty, almost al-dente-like texture) topped with a grilled pork chop, served with sides of grilled shrimp paste, deep-fried bean curd, a fried egg and fish sauce on the side.

name: Dino's Tomato Pie
author: Bethany Jean Clement
description: Unlike Brandon Pettit and partner Molly Wizenberg's revered, restrained Delancey in Ballard, their Capitol Hill pizza joint is old-school all the way including pebbly-textured red plastic water glasses, booths with fake-marble Formica tables and Long Island iced tea. But the proof's in the pie, and Dino's square-format, thick-crust Sicilian version achieves stuff-it-in-your-face, Jersey-style greatness.

name: Saboteur Bakery
author: Bethany Jean Clement
description: The secret of this excellent Navy-town spot is that the baker was formerly the pastry chef of two Michelin-starred restaurants.

name: Kama'aina Grindz
author: Mark Yuasa
description: Head to this spot in downtown Everett for some refined and artistic Hawaiian dishes — and we aren't talking mayo-based macaroni salad. Try the ahi poke, fish tacos and the smoked chicken"Bumbucha' wonton salad.

name: Standard Bakery
author: Tyrone Beason
description: After building a following as a pop-up pastry shop, Josh Grunig's Standard Bakery now has a permanent home in South Lake Union. Stop in for a flaky pastry, such as a marionberry pocket pie, or try one of their daily-changing croissant-based breakfast sandwiches.

name: Greenbridge Cafe
author: Susan Kelleher
description: Greenbridge Cafe brings its A-game with fresh, local ingredients and a menu that changes with the seasons. Affordable meals include everything from steak to squash tacos and gluten-free options. Try the chilaquiles, the house-roasted roast beef or anything with the roasted poblano sauce.

name: Arashi Ramen
author: Tan Vinh
description: A tonkotsu ramen shop that earned a fan base in the south end has now ventured north to Seattle. Its "Arashi Ramen' bowl is its most hearty, though for something different try its black garlic or the tantan men, the latter a sesame paste ramen.

name: Mamnoon Street
author: Bethany Jean Clement
description: From the owners of Capitol Hill's beloved Mamnoon comes Mamnoon Street, a quick-serve spot in the center of Amazonland. It's much like the to-go part of the original restaurant, but with a couple key additions: an extremely good chicken shawarma and a bar. Get the fries; they're nice and spicy, and they come with a za'atar mayonnaise that you'll want to spread on everything in sight.

name: Little Ting's Dumplings
author: Mark Yuasa
description: Competition is fierce in the dumpling world, but family-run Little Ting's, with its cute entryway signage featuring a smiling dumpling, is staking its claim. Don't miss the pan-fried pork buns and the boiled dumplings, both with delicious flavor and nice texture. And if you can't get enough of the dumplings, drop in for a 50-piece bag to keep at home.

name: Mantra
author: Tyrone Beason
description: This new Thai joint near Seattle Center brings in ingredients fresh daily, and you can tell. The food is bright and flavorful, and the lunch combos offer great bang for the buck. Each comes with vegetable pad thai, rice and your choice of a few entrees" plus a bowl of spicy, tangy tom yum soup.

name: 909 Coffee & Wine
author: Susan Kelleher
description: Enjoy a casual lunch date at this spot. The cafe shares a menu and patio with an adjoining bar, called 913 The Place Next Door. This side feels more relaxed, with a warm vibe and friendly service. The menu includes an extensive list of salads and panini sandwiches, and don't miss the crab crepes.

name: Melt
author: Tan Vinh
description: Melt does over-the-top takes on mac-and-cheese and different spins on grilled cheese sandwiches. Fries are covered in cheddar cheese and bacon or decked out as poutine. You get where this menu is going. Melt is a walk-up window located inside the stellar whiskey joint Bar Sue.

name: Sunset Fried Chicken Sandwiches
author: Bethany Jean Clement
description: Monica Dimas just might make the best fried-chicken sandwich in Seattle. Her not-so-secret: rich, lush thigh meat instead of often-dry breast. Her sandwiches are just the right size and they'll leave you with stomach space for sides like cushy hush puppies, tartly lovely fried green tomatoes or, if your arteries so require, a kale Caesar.

name: Grinders Hot Sands
author: Mark Yuasa
description: This Shoreline spot — set amid a blurring row of strip malls off Aurora Avenue — has raised the bar on what a sandwich should be. Don't miss the fully loaded Stromboli, filled with grilled pepperoni and salami. But you can't do wrong with anything served on its signature, lightly toasted, yet still very soft Italian bread.

name: Mi La Cay
author: Tyrone Beason
description: This institution for lovers of authentic Vietnamese cuisine was forced to move due to" you guessed it" redevelopment of its old building. But it seems to be fitting in quite well in its spot in a Little Saigon shopping plaza. The house noodle soup, made with fried shrimp, pork and fried chicken, is not to miss. Enjoy it with a salted plum lemonade or a tamarind drink.

name: Bok A Bok
author: Tan Vinh
description: The Korean Fried Chicken joint in White Center has sold out every night in the first month it opened, one of the most talked about eateries to debut in the South End in recent memory. It's best offerings are the fatty boneless thigh meat over a bed of rice and those magical wings (brined and double-fried) that seem to stay crunchy for hours.

name: Steak 'n Shake
author: Bethany Jean Clement
description: Something about this beloved Midwestern burger chain seems to have been lost in transplantation. The good: The floors are very clean, a product of what appears to be near-constant mopping; beer is served; there are booths. The not-so-good: bland Signature Steakburgers; the greasy, leaden Frisco Melt; dry, listless fries; a chocolate shake that'd be impossible to identify as chocolate in a blind taste test. Seattle's Steak 'n Shake is a sorrowful place.

name: Preserve and Gather
author: Rebekah Denn
description: The sandwich board outside will tell you if Preserve and Gather is your kind of place: 'Coffee, pastry, pickles, snacks, beer/wine.' There's no Wi-Fi at this Greenwood spot, another self-selecting factor for fans and foes (the owners are trying to encourage a more social environment). But you will find thoughtful attention to ingredients and an interesting twist to almost every dish.

name: Shug's Soda Fountain & Ice Cream
author: Paige Collins
description: Ice cream, shakes, malts, sundaes, floats: The sweet options abound at this adorable addition to Pike Place Market. Sit at the counter and admire the shiny antique soda fountain dating back to the 1930s, and definitely order something with one of their house-made soda syrups. The Shugsicle, the signature float made with orange soda and a scoop of vanilla ice cream from Lopez Island Creamery, is not to miss.

name: Mo & Lu Pasta Co.
author: Tan Vinh
description: One of the better meals you can get in the North End for the price. Try the chicken meatballs, one of the best in Seattle. Or the much-loved mushroom lasagna. Each meal comes with a side of focaccia bread. Bring your own wine. No corkage fee.

name: Xi'an Noodles
author: Bethany Jean Clement
description: At this unassuming place on the Ave, owner Lily Wu painstakingly hand-makes biang biang noodles at the crack of dawn daily, and they're some of Seattle's (and maybe the world's) best. Wu moved back to China for two full years to study how to get this Shaanxi province specialty exactly right; wide and flat, with irregular, hand-torn edges, her biang biang have a marvelous, bouncy, slightly al dente bite, and they're extremely difficult to stop eating. Also excellent: the simply named Cold Noodles (aka rangpi).

name: Chili's South Indian Cuisine
author: Jill Lightner
description: South Indian food is a rarity in Seattle, and Chili's is beloved for good reason. On this menu you'll spot only one or two of the north Indian classics you find all over town. Ordering a thali takes some of the decision-making out of your hands; four small bowls of assorted curries are served with rice and your choice of flatbread. Try that, and the Kerala chicken masala.

name: Dumplings of Fury
author: Tan Vinh
description: Dumplings of Fury has become one of the new 'It' spots, bringing a taste of Asian street food to West Seattle, with lines around the block for soup dumplings, or xiao long bao. The pan-fried mandu-inspired dumplings may be the most satisfying morsels, though, and steamed wontons are the best consolation prize when the hit-or-miss, but uber-popular soup dumplings sell out.

name: Sixth Avenue Eats
author: Paige Collins
description: Not quite at Seattle Center, but not quite in South Lake Union, this secret lunch wonder lives on the otherwise deserted corner of Sixth and Thomas. The tiny family-run sandwich shack uses all-local ingredients and piles fries high with meaty, cheesy goodness. Choose between 19 sandwiches, all served on Grand Central Bakery baguettes, with sauces ranging from spicy mayo to blueberry chipotle and marionberry-sage.

name: Ramen Bushi-Do
author: Tan Vinh
description: Two years in the making, this Eastside ramen house comes with high expectation given that its pedigree is Dough Zone, the much loved soup dumpling spot that has expanded with three locations. Get the scalding Tonkotsu miso with al dente noodles for a thick, wheaty bite. The cuts of chatsu pork weren't fatty but the broth was so rich and creamy, they didn't need to be. For appetizers, get the crispy fried chicken karaage and the little umami bombs of 'mini spinach towers' coated in sesame and bonito.

name: Peloton
author: Bethany Jean Clement
description: At this half bike-shop/half cafe, you'll encounter the very good food of co-owner Mckenzie Hart, whose credentials include Cafe Presse, Sitka & Spruce and The London Plane. The same shortish menu is served all day (except Taco Thursdays, evenings only). From breakfast burritos to heaps of salad, it all shows the kind of thought and care that's rare (especially at these prices). And you can get your bike tuned up.

name: Cheese Wizards
author: Paige Collins
description: Making the perfect grilled cheese takes magic, and at Cheese Wizards grilled-cheese mastery has been achieved far beyond Muggle abilities. The sandwiches have the perfect crunch and a cheesy, gooey center. And the tomato soup is creamy and fragrant with basil, tasting so fresh you'll wonder if they robbed Professor Sprout's greenhouse.

name: Vif
author: Rebekah Denn
description: Avocado toast and house-made pickles in a small cafe/wine shop? Yes, it's trendy. But Vif is also excellent. Everything off the short, order-at-the-counter menu is fresh, inspired, composed with care and beautifully seasoned. It's vegetarian-friendly (but with some fish and meat) and influenced by the Mediterranean, Middle East and Europe. Expect a lot of grains, beans, greens and eggs.

name: Seattle Fish Guys
author: Bethany Jean Clement
description: Oyster shooters in an upscale fish market at 23rd and Jackson?! Change in the Central District is too deep to get into here, but Seattle Fish Guys has real neighborhood ties. The owners are Desiree Chinn, whose dad graduated from Garfield High School back in 1949, and Sal Panelo, whose family owns Linc's Fishing Tackle over on Rainier. Sal's also got decades of experience at Mutual Fish, Pike Place Market Fish and more. They're as nice as can be, and they're serving very good poke, seafood cocktail and chowder in their gleaming, spacious shop.

name: Beach Bakery
author: Jill Lightner
description: Everything is so good at Rainier Beach's Beach Bakery that there's clearly magic afoot. Owned by a longtime Rainier Valley restaurateur, this spot is comfortable enough that you'll feel like a regular by your second visit. The menu runs the gamut from Seattle-style seasonal fruit scones and muffins to Filipino cassata cake and a spectacular rainbow six-layer cake for Pride weekend. Check out the menu of custom cakes for your next occasion.

name: The Atlantic
author: Tan Vinh
description: This rustic chic restaurant does slight tweaks on comfort food and the classics, from avocado toast to a beef-tongue French Dip, but most order the"New School Burger'- two patties stacked with Beecher's cheese and a foliage of arugula and pickled onions on a Macrina ciabatta. It's the usual gooey, salty, greasy double burger but made distinctive with a secret sauce that tastes like a cross between an aioli and salsa verde. The kitchen also smokes its own salmon and bacon.

name: Korochka Tavern
author: Julia Wayne
description: On Lake City Way, you’ll find a charming, chic and comfortable bar with great beer and a homey menu of Russian bites. Order a giant loaded baked potato, or snack on some pelmeni, stuffed with beef and pork, or piroshki. Wash it all down with a rotating draught selection.

name: Reunion Bake Brew Bite
author: Paige Collins
description: This small cafe makes its food with local, sustainable and organic stuff whenever possible. Reunion’s a friendly place. The name conjures up family, and the Bake (pastries), Brew (all sorts of coffees) and Bite (sandwiches, salads and more) are all on offer, too.

name: Szechuan Fish
author: Tan Vinh
description: The namesake dish is wildly popular, drawing long lines on weekends. It’s a sizzling fish, served whole or in boneless chunks with choice of two proteins and two veggie sides, all simmering in a muddy, garlicky sauce with at least a hundred dried red chiles.

name: Ooink Ramen
author: Bethany Jean Clement
description: The extra “o” in Ooink comes from the surname of chef Chong Boon Ooi, who meticulously assembles each bowl of ramen at his tiny shop, using metal chopsticks to gently, swiftly turn the noodles, adding toppings with precision. His business partner (and wife) Jiaxin Wang says that their spicy kotteri ramen is the most clamored for, made with extra-luscious broth courtesy of se-abura (pork back fat). The miso ramen inspires awe with its delicate richness. At Ooink, you may very well find the best bowl of ramen you’ve ever had.

name: Phorale
author: Tan Vinh
description: Located inside a convenience store, this lunch counter serves a pho-ramen hybrid and egg rolls that riff on chimichangas. But the best are its banh mis stuffed with bulgogi or other Korean-spicy marinated meats and topped with Mexican condiments.

name: Los Pollos Hermanos
author: Rebekah Denn
description: Los Pollos Hermanos’ signature specialty, Pollos a la Brasa is a Peruvian chicken dish that even non-chicken fans can love, a moist, spice-rubbed, four-pound bird with a flavor that permeates throughout the meat rather than being restricted to the skin. It’s a testament to the food’s quality that a sold-out crowd has discovered the Peruvian/Mexican restaurant, hidden away in a strip-mall grocery store.

name: Trove Noodle
author: Providence Cicero
description: Trove isn’t so much a restaurant as a complex. In its priciest zone, Trove BBQ, you can spend $100 for a tower of meat. But at Trove Noodle’s lab-like counter, you can try this Capitol Hill place from the famed chefs of Joule and Revel for much, much less. The chewy discs of rice cake with rich lamb curry are especially good. Scrutinizing the erupting Mount Rainier diorama is free.

name: Feed Co.
author: Tan Vinh
description: Think of it as Uneeda Burger east. Scott Staples, the chef behind that popular Fremont spot as well as Restaurant Zoë and Quinn’s, brings his burger-and-shake concept to Redmond, featuring everything from a basic burger to a bison burger souped-up with truffled crispy potato strings.
